document.title: Stationary phase, Laplace’s method, and the Fourier transform for Gaussian integrals

para.p:
Let
U
be a nonempty open subset of
R n
and let
: ϕ

be smooth. Then
:

The Morse lemma 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Serge Lang, Differential and Riemannian Manifolds, p. 182, chapter VII, Theorem 5.1. states that if
0

para.p:
Let
U
be a nonempty connected open subset of
R n
, and let
:
a , ϕ
→ U R
be smooth functions such that
a
has compact support. Suppose that each
∈ p
∩
C ϕ
⁢ supp a
is nondegenerate. 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 In particular,
ϕ
is called a Morse function if it has no degenerate critical points, and in this case of course each
∈ p
∩
C ϕ
⁢ supp a
is nondegenerate. The stationary phase approximation states that

Math.text: (integral _ U)@(a * x * e ^ (i * t * phi * x) * differential-d@(x)) = (sum _ (p element-of C _ phi intersection supp * a))@(((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * (e ^ ((i * pi * sgn * Hess * phi * p) / 4) / (absolute-value@(determinant@(Hess * phi * p))) ^ (1 / 2)) * e ^ (i * t * phi * p) * a * p)
(integral _ U)@(a * x * e ^ (i * t * phi * x) * differential-d@(x))

absent = (sum _ (p element-of C _ phi intersection supp * a))@(((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * (e ^ ((i * pi * sgn * Hess * phi * p) / 4) / (absolute-value@(determinant@(Hess * phi * p))) ^ (1 / 2)) * e ^ (i * t * phi * p) * a * p)

para.p:
as
→ t ∞
. 5 footnote 5 5 footnote 5 Liviu Nicolaescu, An Invitation to Morse Theory, second ed., p. 183, Proposition 3.88.

Let

para.p:
We calculate
=
⁢ grad ϕ
( x )
⁢ A x
, so
=
C ϕ
{ 0 }
. The Hessian of
ϕ
is
=
⁢ Hess ϕ
( x )
A
, and because
A
is invertible,
0
is indeed a nondegenerate critical point of
ϕ
. Thus we have the following.

p.text:
For a nonempty connected open subset of
R n
and for smooth functions
:
a , ϕ
→ U R
such that
a
has compact support and such that each
∈ p
C ϕ
is nondegenerate,

Math.text: (integral _ U)@(a * x * e ^ ((1 / 2) * list@(A * x, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * (e ^ ((i * pi * sgn * A) / 4) / (absolute-value@(determinant@(A))) ^ (1 / 2)) * e ^ ((1 / 2) * i * t * list@(A * p, p)) * a * p + O * t ^ (- n / 2 - 1)

para.p:

≥

n

Math.text: formulae@(P ^ T * A * P = Lambda, formulae@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2) = diag * vector@((lambda _ 1) ^ (1 / 2), ldots, (lambda _ n) ^ (1 / 2)), A ^ (1 / 2) = P * Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * P ^ T))

para.p:
For
∈ ξ
R n
and
> t 0
, using the change of variables formula with the fact that
=
|
det P
|
1
and then using Fubini’s theorem,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(A * x, x) - i * list@(P * xi, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * P ^ T * x, Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * P ^ T * x) - i * list@(P * xi, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * P ^ T * P * y, Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * P ^ T * P * y) - i * list@(P * xi, P * y)) * absolute-value@(determinant@(P)) * differential-d@(y)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * (norm@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2) * y)) ^ 2 - i * list@(xi, y)) * differential-d@(y)) = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((integral _ R)@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * lambda _ j * (y _ j) ^ 2 - i * xi _ j * y _ j) * differential-d@(y _ j)))

para.p: Using 6 footnote 6 6 footnote 6 http://individual.utoronto.ca/jordanbell/notes/bochnertheorem.pdf

Math.text: formulae@((integral _ R)@(e ^ ((- a * x ^ 2) + b * x + c) * differential-d@(x)) = square-root@(pi / a) * exponential@(b ^ 2 / (4 * a) + c), formulae@(Re * a > list@(0, b), c element-of C))

para.p: gives

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * lambda _ j * (y _ j) ^ 2 - i * xi _ j * y _ j) * differential-d@(y _ j)) = (1 / (lambda _ j) ^ (1 / 2)) * ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (1 / 2) * exponential@(- (xi _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * t * lambda _ j))

para.p:
and using
=
det A
∏
= j 1
n
λ j
we have

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(A * x, x) - i * list@(P * xi, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((1 / (lambda _ j) ^ (1 / 2)) * ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (1 / 2) * exponential@(- (xi _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * t * lambda _ j))) = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@(- (1 / (2 * t)) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((xi _ j) ^ 2 / lambda _ j))

para.p: and because

Math.text: formulae@(Lambda ^ (- 1) * xi = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((xi _ j / lambda _ j) * e _ j), list@(Lambda ^ (- 1) * xi, xi) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((xi _ j) ^ 2 / lambda _ j))

para.p: this becomes

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(A * x, x) - i * list@(P * xi, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@(- (1 / (2 * t)) * list@(Lambda ^ (- 1) * xi, xi)) = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * ((2 * pi) / t) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@(- (1 / (2 * t)) * list@(A ^ (- 1) * P * xi, P * xi))

para.p:
and so, as
P
is invertible we get the following.

When
∈ A

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@(- (1 / 2) * t * list@(A * x, x) - i * list@(xi, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (2 * pi * t ^ (- 1)) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@(- (1 / (2 * t)) * list@(A ^ (- 1) * xi, xi))

para.p:
Let
∈ A
⁢ L
(

be positive and invertible and let
∈ b
R n
. As above,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * list@(A * x, x)) + list@(P * b, x)) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * (norm@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2))) ^ 2) + list@(b, y)) * differential-d@(y))
(integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * list@(A * x, x)) + list@(P * b, x)) * differential-d@(x))
absent = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * (norm@(Lambda ^ (1 / 2))) ^ 2) + list@(b, y)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((integral _ R)@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * lambda _ j * (y _ j) ^ 2) + b _ j * y _ j) * differential-d@(y _ j)))
absent = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((integral _ R)@(exponential@((- (1 / 2) * lambda _ j * (y _ j) ^ 2) + b _ j * y _ j) * differential-d@(y _ j)))
absent = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((2 * pi) ^ (1 / 2) / (lambda _ j) ^ (1 / 2)) * exponential@((b _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * lambda _ j)))
absent = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((2 * pi) ^ (1 / 2) / (lambda _ j) ^ (1 / 2)) * exponential@((b _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * lambda _ j)))
absent = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (2 * pi) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@((1 / 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((b _ j) ^ 2 / lambda _ j))
absent = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (2 * pi) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@((1 / 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((b _ j) ^ 2 / lambda _ j))
absent = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (2 * pi) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@((1 / 2) * list@(A ^ (- 1) * P * b, P * b))
absent = (determinant@(A)) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (2 * pi) ^ (n / 2) * exponential@((1 / 2) * list@(A ^ (- 1) * P * b, P * b))

para.p:
which gives the following. 7 footnote 7 7 footnote 7 cf. Gaussian measures on

: http://individual.utoronto.ca/jordanbell/notes/gaussian.pdf

para.p:
Let
D

and radius
1

>

: g

> t 0

Math.text: J * t = (integral _ D)@(e ^ (- t * S * x) * g * x * differential-d@(x))
